0.39.text:
Do you have any views on the role of mentors
and the development of these competencies

10.13.text: Let me ask an open question, if I may

22.50.text:
Well, there’s a lot of talk these days about
21st century skills and I go along with a

28.53.text:
great deal of it, my only reservation about
the idea of 21st century skills is that when

32.99.text:
they’re listed, they often include skills
that were relevant at any time, in any century,

36.51.text:
it’s not that they’re a completely brand
new set of things that people need to learn

40.33.text:
now that they didn’t have to learn before, but
the context is very different.

45.17.text:
We live in a world that’s growing very quickly
in terms of population, which is producing

49.86.text:
great strains on the environment.
It’s producing enormous cultural pressures,

53.93.text:
it’s changing the economic landscape.
We’re challenging our relationship with

60.07.text:
the earth in a very fundamental way, we don’t
know if we can continue for long this way

63.94.text:
so the issues of sustainability and new forms
of economic practice we need to develop and

69.30.text:
the world’s becoming more complicated in
all sorts of ways.

73.13.text:
The capacity for new thinking and for turning
old ideas into new applications has really

79.22.text:
never been more important, and I think our
kids ought to recognize how deep their capacities

85.82.text:
for creativity are.
People often think it’s a rather vague term

88.54.text:
that can’t be defined.
I’ve spend a bit of time trying to convince

91.70.text:
people you can define it, it’s the process
of having original ideas that have value,

97.01.text:
and it’s the fruit of imagination, it’s
applied imagination and it can be present,

103.54.text:
evident, developed in almost every part of
the curriculum.

107.72.text:
Not just the arts, but in science, technology,
the world is crying out for fresh thinking,

111.88.text:
new ideas.
A second is compassion.

116.55.text:
Compassion is rooted in empathy and empathy
is our ability to step into other people’s

121.17.text:
point of view to see the world as they see
it.

122.92.text:
To try and take that perspective and it comes
from the same power of imagination of seeing

128.86.text:
things away from our immediate circumstances.
I think of compassion as applied empathy,

136.52.text:
so to speak, the executive wing of empathy,
it’s...we won’t think to empathize with

141.35.text:
somebody else’s situation…it’s something
else to do something about it.

145.01.text:
And to decide either to act on behalf of somebody
or to prevent others acting against them.

150.93.text:
So compassion to me is fundamental to our
ability to be together as communities, as

156.18.text:
it’s this sort of cultural, glue that holds
us together into communities.

161.75.text:
So active compassion to me is very important
and that begins with self-understanding and

167.09.text:
it relates to mindfulness, which I think of
as composure.

169.86.text:
I mean the ability to be centered in yourself.
A lot of young people, and not only young

175.89.text:
people, all sorts of people, I think find
themselves off balance in various ways.

180.54.text:
You only have to look at the figures for depression.
According to World Health Organization, by

185.76.text:
2020, depression will be the second largest
cause of disability in human populations.

190.28.text:
This is in a world that’s growing materially
better off all the time.

194.40.text:
What it points to is a spiritual deficit in
our lives, and I don’t mean that in the

199.48.text:
religious sense, I don’t not mean it the
religious sense, but I don’t mean it just

203.59.text:
in a limited faith-based way, whatever the
faith happens to be.

206.40.text:
I’m talking about the sense of our internal
energy whether we feel balanced or out of

212.07.text:
balance. Whether we feel whole or disjointed
with ourselves.

216.49.text:
And the fourth one I’d mention is collaboration.
We do live in school systems, which are more

222.58.text:
and more based on competition and win-win
and individualism, that’s an agenda that’s

228.74.text:
being sadly driven harder by the international
lead tables where kids are competing against

233.41.text:
each other for limited places in other institutions,
and schools are being drawn to compete with

238.66.text:
each other for limited resources, and countries
are competing with each other for dominance

243.45.text:
in these league tables, and there’s a place
for competition, but there’s a much more

247.24.text:
important place for collaboration.
This seeing we face common challenges and

251.00.text:
we’re more likely to solve them if we work
together rather than push against each other.

255.47.text:
All of these areas are actually rather subtle
and complicated in themselves and people need to be trained themselves to do it.

266.00.text: We got very used to these safety announcements

268.38.text:
on aircrafts, you know, when they tell about
when the oxygen tanks shoot comes down, and

272.42.text:
they always say put your own mask on first, before
you try and help somebody else.

276.58.text:
So one of the keys to developing these capacities
in students is first to attend to helping

281.51.text:
teachers develop them in themselves.
Teachers have tremendous creative resources,

285.36.text:
but they’re often not encouraged or trained
to develop them.

288.87.text:
They have their own needs to develop their
capacities of composure and empathy, but they

293.19.text:
don’t have the techniques either, not all
of them, but very many, it doesn’t feature

296.45.text:
in teacher education very much.
Mentoring is, I think, an essential part of

300.10.text:
teaching, and of education more generally.
A mentor is somebody who helps you identify

307.17.text:
your own interests, your own talents, your
own strengths, and mitigate your weaknesses,

310.89.text:
but also it does more than that.
A mentor is somebody who can also help you

315.00.text:
open doors, point you in a direction to move
in, and I know in my own life that I’ve

320.38.text:
had all kinds of mentors that didn’t have
mentor on the door, they were just people

324.32.text:
who took an interest in me, people I met,
often teachers, who saw something in me that

329.24.text:
I didn’t see in myself, who took a shine
to something I was capable in doing and encouraged it.

332.13.text: Great teachers have always naturally taken

335.05.text:
on that sort of role.
They take an interest in their students and

338.23.text:
recognize that to be a teacher isn’t just
about teaching the discipline, in some direct

343.92.text:
way.
Teachers also empower kids so they gain proper

350.53.text:
confidence in their own abilities.
Seeing the professional growth of the teacher

357.24.text:
as part of the evolution of education, I think,
is absolutely critically important.
